comment: Anand has played the Sicilian Defense, Spanish Game (Open or closed variations) , Scandinavian Defense and (against some opponents) the French Defense or Caro-Kann Defense. Recently he has been playing the Sicilian Defense with ...e6.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7
comment: Black's opening seems particularly aimed at preventing any Sozin-like variation (Qc7 makes Bf1-c4 unlikely) or a Richter (Bc1-g5 to pin a Nf6) as there is no Nf6. So, White develops more quietly and will latch onto a concrete plan a bit later, after he's seen how Black has developed.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8
comment: With this short flurry White has the two bishops and a simpler pawn formation. It's the next phase of the game which will resolve whether those two bishops are powerful.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5
comment: Earlier in the tournament Shirov played 14. Qd3, which gave a small advantage.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5 Nd5 15. c4
comment: Kasparov advances pawns to help ensure Black's pieces get chased around and Pd7 stays backward (gaining a grip on d6) . But, in so doing he makes moves like ...f7-f6xe5 possible, and he blocks the attack on Pa6 (however slight or insignificant that might seem) .

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5 Nd5 15. c4 Nf4 16. Bf3
comment: This is a far less desirable square for the bishop than d3, but I suppose it is heading to e4.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5 Nd5 15. c4 Nf4 16. Bf3 Qc7 17. Re1 Ng6 18. c5
comment: One of the curious aspects of this kind of position is the difficulty of getting at Pd7, despite it being on an open file and almost indefensible. Defense of the exposed Pe5 and Pb2 keep White busy.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5 Nd5 15. c4 Nf4 16. Bf3 Qc7 17. Re1 Ng6 18. c5 f6
comment: Anand doesn't wait for Bf3-e4xg6 because that would weaken his king's position, probably making a later ...f7-f6 impossible.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5 Nd5 15. c4 Nf4 16. Bf3 Qc7 17. Re1 Ng6 18. c5 f6 19. exf6 Bxf6 20. Be4 Nf4 21. Bxf6 Rxf6
comment: With two open files occupied by rooks it appears Black has adequate compensation for the backward Pd7. All those Black pawns on light squares limit Be4 (only Ph7 is truly exposed to the bishop)

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5 Nd5 15. c4 Nf4 16. Bf3 Qc7 17. Re1 Ng6 18. c5 f6 19. exf6 Bxf6 20. Be4 Nf4 21. Bxf6 Rxf6 22. Qc2 h6 23. Rad1 Nd5 24. g3
comment: It's not so easy for Black to find a very good plan here. Certainly Pa2, Pb2 and Pc5 are worth attacking, but he must also realize White can fight with f2-f4-f5 to undermine Nd5 and to weaken Kg8. There is also Bxd5 cxd5 to mobilize Pc5. White holds the central files and Black has to use his long-distance pieces (queen and rooks) to work from the edges, hitting all the crucial points.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5 Nd5 15. c4 Nf4 16. Bf3 Qc7 17. Re1 Ng6 18. c5 f6 19. exf6 Bxf6 20. Be4 Nf4 21. Bxf6 Rxf6 22. Qc2 h6 23. Rad1 Nd5 24. g3 a5 25. a3
comment: Before committing to such weakening moves as f2-f4 he prevents ...Nd5-b4, which would gain a valuable tempo, hitting Qc2. This also prevents ...Rb8-b4.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5 Nd5 15. c4 Nf4 16. Bf3 Qc7 17. Re1 Ng6 18. c5 f6 19. exf6 Bxf6 20. Be4 Nf4 21. Bxf6 Rxf6 22. Qc2 h6 23. Rad1 Nd5 24. g3 a5 25. a3 Rff8
comment: I suppose he might have an idea of adding pressure on the b-file with doubled rooks, but it seems unlikely this could succeed and he would be removing a valuable defender from his king.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5 Nd5 15. c4 Nf4 16. Bf3 Qc7 17. Re1 Ng6 18. c5 f6 19. exf6 Bxf6 20. Be4 Nf4 21. Bxf6 Rxf6 22. Qc2 h6 23. Rad1 Nd5 24. g3 a5 25. a3 Rff8 26. Re2 Qd8
comment: So, Anand brings Qd8 toward the king-side, but that would leave Pa5 weaker. How does he think this will succeed?

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5 Nd5 15. c4 Nf4 16. Bf3 Qc7 17. Re1 Ng6 18. c5 f6 19. exf6 Bxf6 20. Be4 Nf4 21. Bxf6 Rxf6 22. Qc2 h6 23. Rad1 Nd5 24. g3 a5 25. a3 Rff8 26. Re2 Qd8 27. Rd4 Rb7 28. Bh7+ Kh8 29. Bd3
comment: White's pieces look active, but they get in each other's way. Ideally he'd like to get his queen in front of Bd3 (at e4 for example) to attack Kh8, but he can't because Re2 is in the way. All the weaknesses put demands on his pieces and they're not free to just attack.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5 Nd5 15. c4 Nf4 16. Bf3 Qc7 17. Re1 Ng6 18. c5 f6 19. exf6 Bxf6 20. Be4 Nf4 21. Bxf6 Rxf6 22. Qc2 h6 23. Rad1 Nd5 24. g3 a5 25. a3 Rff8 26. Re2 Qd8 27. Rd4 Rb7 28. Bh7+ Kh8 29. Bd3 Qf6 30. Ra4 Ra8 31. Qd2 Qd8 32. Bb1 Rb5
comment: This is consistent with his plan to defend Pa5 and threaten Pc5, but Rb5 can't easily get to the king-side for defense. Black depends upon his queen, knight and possibly Ra8 to defend the king-side. White might be able to bring all his pieces to bear on the king-side.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5 Nd5 15. c4 Nf4 16. Bf3 Qc7 17. Re1 Ng6 18. c5 f6 19. exf6 Bxf6 20. Be4 Nf4 21. Bxf6 Rxf6 22. Qc2 h6 23. Rad1 Nd5 24. g3 a5 25. a3 Rff8 26. Re2 Qd8 27. Rd4 Rb7 28. Bh7+ Kh8 29. Bd3 Qf6 30. Ra4 Ra8 31. Qd2 Qd8 32. Bb1 Rb5 33. Rh4 Qe7
comment: This is a gutsy move. It allows White to win Ph6 and continues the plan to pressure White's queen-side. Or, perhaps he just overlooked that Kasparov might capture Ph6.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5 Nd5 15. c4 Nf4 16. Bf3 Qc7 17. Re1 Ng6 18. c5 f6 19. exf6 Bxf6 20. Be4 Nf4 21. Bxf6 Rxf6 22. Qc2 h6 23. Rad1 Nd5 24. g3 a5 25. a3 Rff8 26. Re2 Qd8 27. Rd4 Rb7 28. Bh7+ Kh8 29. Bd3 Qf6 30. Ra4 Ra8 31. Qd2 Qd8 32. Bb1 Rb5 33. Rh4 Qe7 34. Rxh6+ Kg8 35. Rh4 Rab8 36. Bh7+ Kf7 37. Qd3 Qg5
comment: This seems aggressive because he's keeping his king safe and still expecting to break through on the queen-side. To capture Pb2 and allow White to succeed in the attack on Kf7 wouldn't be good. But, however scary it may seem, it's not clear White has anything.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5 Nd5 15. c4 Nf4 16. Bf3 Qc7 17. Re1 Ng6 18. c5 f6 19. exf6 Bxf6 20. Be4 Nf4 21. Bxf6 Rxf6 22. Qc2 h6 23. Rad1 Nd5 24. g3 a5 25. a3 Rff8 26. Re2 Qd8 27. Rd4 Rb7 28. Bh7+ Kh8 29. Bd3 Qf6 30. Ra4 Ra8 31. Qd2 Qd8 32. Bb1 Rb5 33. Rh4 Qe7 34. Rxh6+ Kg8 35. Rh4 Rab8 36. Bh7+ Kf7 37. Qd3 Qg5 38. Qd4 Rxb2
comment: a tactical trick in time trouble? If 39. Rxb2 Qc1+ regains the rook.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nc6 5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Be2 a6 7. O-O Nf6 8. Be3 Bb4 9. Na4 Be7 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. Nb6 Rb8 12. Nxc8 Qxc8 13. Bd4 O-O 14. e5 Nd5 15. c4 Nf4 16. Bf3 Qc7 17. Re1 Ng6 18. c5 f6 19. exf6 Bxf6 20. Be4 Nf4 21. Bxf6 Rxf6 22. Qc2 h6 23. Rad1 Nd5 24. g3 a5 25. a3 Rff8 26. Re2 Qd8 27. Rd4 Rb7 28. Bh7+ Kh8 29. Bd3 Qf6 30. Ra4 Ra8 31. Qd2 Qd8 32. Bb1 Rb5 33. Rh4 Qe7 34. Rxh6+ Kg8 35. Rh4 Rab8 36. Bh7+ Kf7 37. Qd3 Qg5 38. Qd4 Rxb2 39. Bg6+ Kg8 40. Bh7+ Kf7 41. Bg6+ Kg8 42. Bh7+
comment: The complications can be overwhelming and the players choose not to lose when they don't see a way to win. For example, Anand could have tried 42...Kf8 to end the attacking checks, hoping for time to continue his plan. But, being down a pawn and seeing Kasparov grasping at perpetual check, he probably felt like it was a good idea to draw.
